channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: How I’m supporting other researchers who have moved to Lithuania
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01142-0

Biochemist Stephen Knox Jones chose a role in the Baltic country over other faculty positions in Denmark and the United States. He explains why.
item.dc:title: How I’m supporting other researchers who have moved to Lithuania
item.dc:creator: Jacqui Thornton

item.title: Chinese virologist who was first to share COVID genome sleeps on street after lab shuts
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01293-0

Zhang Yongzhen shared the genomic sequence of SARS-CoV-2 with the world, speeding the development of vaccines.
item.dc:title: Chinese virologist who was first to share COVID genome sleeps on street after lab shuts
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: Scientists tried to give people COVID — and failed
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01284-1

Researchers deliberately infect participants with SARS-CoV-2 in ‘challenge’ trials — but high levels of immunity complicate efforts to test vaccines and treatments.
item.dc:title: Scientists tried to give people COVID — and failed
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: I fell out of love with the lab, and in love with business
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01140-2

The COVID-19 pandemic changed Karolina Makovskytė’s career ambitions, propelling her to a business development role in her home nation of Lithuania.
item.dc:title: I fell out of love with the lab, and in love with business
item.dc:creator: Jacqui Thornton

item.title: How to meet Africa’s grand challenges with African know-how
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01249-4

Simple measures to strengthen the interface between science, policy and society in African nations could help the continent leapfrog others in sustainable innovation and development.
item.dc:title: How to meet Africa’s grand challenges with African know-how
item.dc:creator: Alfred R. Bizoza

item.title: How bioinformatics led one scientist home to Lithuania
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01141-1

Juozas Gordevičius founded a data-science company in the United States before returning to Vilnius.
item.dc:title: How bioinformatics led one scientist home to Lithuania
item.dc:creator: Jacqui Thornton

item.title: A snapshot of Lithuania’s life-sciences landscape
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01139-9

Nature examines the Baltic country’s research ambitions as it marks 20 years of European Union membership.
item.dc:title: A snapshot of Lithuania’s life-sciences landscape
item.dc:creator: Jacqui Thornton

item.title: Support communities that will lose out in the energy transition
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01248-5

Climate campaigners and politicians rightly concentrate on the benefits of clean energy — but without more support for those who are adversely affected, the backlash will only grow.
item.dc:title: Support communities that will lose out in the energy transition

item.title: Why it was right to reject the Anthropocene as a geological epoch
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01268-1

Why it was right to reject the Anthropocene as a geological epoch
item.dc:title: Why it was right to reject the Anthropocene as a geological epoch
item.dc:creator: Mark Maslin
Matthew Edgeworth
Erle C. Ellis
Philip L. Gibbard

item.title: How to stop students cramming for exams? Send them to sea
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01209-y

An innovative proposal to stop exam over-preparation, plus William Bateson’s 1924 take on the previous century of biology, in the weekly dip into Nature’s archive.
item.dc:title: How to stop students cramming for exams? Send them to sea

item.title: Not just truffles: dogs can sniff out surpassingly rare native fungus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01263-6

Daisy, a member of a breed used to find fungal delicacies, detected a critically endangered Australian fungus faster than a trained human could.
item.dc:title: Not just truffles: dogs can sniff out surpassingly rare native fungus

item.title: Corrosion is a global menace to crucial infrastructure — act to stop the rot now
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01270-7

Corrosion is a global menace to crucial infrastructure — act to stop the rot now
item.dc:title: Corrosion is a global menace to crucial infrastructure — act to stop the rot now
item.dc:creator: Weichen Xu
Ruiyong Zhang
Jizhou Duan
Donald Terry Greenfield

item.title: Zoos should focus on animal welfare before claiming to champion conservation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01269-0

Zoos should focus on animal welfare before claiming to champion conservation
item.dc:title: Zoos should focus on animal welfare before claiming to champion conservation
item.dc:creator: Donald Broom
Hsiao Mei Yeh
Shawn Peng

item.title: Climate-targets group should rescind its endorsement of carbon offsets
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01271-6

Climate-targets group should rescind its endorsement of carbon offsets
item.dc:title: Climate-targets group should rescind its endorsement of carbon offsets
item.dc:creator: William R. L. Anderegg
Libby Blanchard

item.title: AI & robotics briefing: What running robots tell us about gaits
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01307-x

A robot that changes from trot to bounce to avoid falls hints at why four-legged animals transition between gaits. Plus, AI designs new gene-editing tools and how autonomous weapons are changing war.
item.dc:title: AI & robotics briefing: What running robots tell us about gaits
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: The science of 3 Body Problem: what’s fact and what’s fiction?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01272-5

Nature spoke to the sci-fi program’s adviser and two other researchers about the portrayal of PhD scientists and their technologies.
item.dc:title: The science of 3 Body Problem: what’s fact and what’s fiction?
item.dc:creator: Sumeet Kulkarni

item.title: This social sciences hub galvanized India’s dynamic growth. Can it survive?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00944-6

The Centre for Policy Research has lost its chief executive, most of its staff and is running out of cash.
item.dc:title: This social sciences hub galvanized India’s dynamic growth. Can it survive?
item.dc:creator: Michele Catanzaro

item.title: First fetus-to-fetus transplant demonstrated in rats
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01152-y

The tissue developed into functioning kidneys and produced urine.
item.dc:title: First fetus-to-fetus transplant demonstrated in rats
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: What China’s mission to collect rocks from the Moon's far side could reveal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01056-x

The Chang’e-6 mission aims to land in the Moon’s oldest and largest crater, where it will collect rocks to bring back to Earth.
item.dc:title: What China’s mission to collect rocks from the Moon's far side could reveal
item.dc:creator: Ling Xin

item.title: Why doing science is difficult in India today
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01214-1

With an election under way, the future of Indian science is on the ballot. Encouraging research and critical thinking should be a priority for the new government.
item.dc:title: Why doing science is difficult in India today
item.dc:creator: Yamini Aiyar

item.title: Do cutting-edge CAR-T-cell therapies cause cancer? What the data say
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01215-0

Regulators have identified around 30 cases of cancer linked to this blockbuster treatment. But is CAR T to blame? The hunt is on for answers.
item.dc:title: Do cutting-edge CAR-T-cell therapies cause cancer? What the data say
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Willyard

item.title: Author Correction: Targeting DCAF5 suppresses SMARCB1-mutant cancer by stabilizing SWI/SNF
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07402-3

Author Correction: Targeting DCAF5 suppresses SMARCB1-mutant cancer by stabilizing SWI/SNF
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Targeting DCAF5 suppresses SMARCB1-mutant cancer by stabilizing SWI/SNF

item.title: I strive to make the Great Barrier Reef more resilient to heat stress
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01218-x

Matthew Nitschke grows coral symbionts in a slowly warming tank to prepare reef life for climate change.
item.dc:title: I strive to make the Great Barrier Reef more resilient to heat stress
item.dc:creator: James Mitchell Crow

item.title: Epic blazes threaten Arctic permafrost. Can fire-fighters save it?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01168-4

Some scientists argue that it’s time to rethink the blanket policy of letting blazes burn themselves out in northern wildernesses.
item.dc:title: Epic blazes threaten Arctic permafrost. Can fire-fighters save it?
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: Superconductivity hunt gets boost from China's $220 million physics 'playground'
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01192-4

From extreme cold to strong magnets and high pressures, the Synergetic Extreme Condition User Facility (SECUF) provides conditions for researching these potential wonder materials.
item.dc:title: Superconductivity hunt gets boost from China's $220 million physics 'playground'
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Elephant-nose fish ‘see’ farther by electric sensing when in groups
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00464-3

The elephant-nose fish senses its environment by emitting electrical pulses. A multi-pronged investigation suggests that this remarkable sensing ability is amplified in social groups by individuals ‘listening in’ on the pulses of their neighbours.
item.dc:title: Elephant-nose fish ‘see’ farther by electric sensing when in groups

item.title: How reliable is this research? Tool flags papers discussed on PubPeer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01247-6

Browser plug-in alerts users when studies — or their references — have been posted on a site known for raising integrity concerns.
item.dc:title: How reliable is this research? Tool flags papers discussed on PubPeer
item.dc:creator: Dalmeet Singh Chawla

item.title: 85 million cells — and counting — at your fingertips
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01217-y

Chan Zuckerberg CELL by GENE Discover aims to be a one-stop shop for single-cell RNA sequencing data storage, access and analysis.
item.dc:title: 85 million cells — and counting — at your fingertips
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey M. Perkel

item.title: ‘ChatGPT for CRISPR’ creates new gene-editing tools
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01243-w

Some of the AI-designed gene editors could be more versatile than those found in nature.
item.dc:title: ‘ChatGPT for CRISPR’ creates new gene-editing tools
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Bird flu virus has been spreading among US cows for months, RNA reveals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01256-5

Genomic analysis suggests that the outbreak probably began in December or January, but a shortage of data is hampering efforts to pin down the source.
item.dc:title: Bird flu virus has been spreading among US cows for months, RNA reveals
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: Audio long read: Why loneliness is bad for your health
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01251-w

New research is revealing the mechanisms linking loneliness and conditions like dementia, depression and cardiovascular disease.
item.dc:title: Audio long read: Why loneliness is bad for your health
item.dc:creator: Saima May Sidik
Benjamin Thompson

item.title: Could a rare mutation that causes dwarfism also slow ageing?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01201-6

People with Laron syndrome have a low risk of heart disease and a number of other age-related disorders, hinting at strategies for new treatments.
item.dc:title: Could a rare mutation that causes dwarfism also slow ageing?
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Daily briefing: Gaze upon the most detailed Moon maps ever made
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01266-3

The new Geologic Atlas took more than 100 researchers over a decade to compile. Plus, how gliding marsupials got their ‘wings’ and H5N1 bird flu virus material has been detected in US milk.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Gaze upon the most detailed Moon maps ever made
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Want to make a difference? Try working at an environmental non-profit organization
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01257-4

Moving to non-profit work requires researchers to shift their mindset to focus on applied science for policymaking and conservation practice.
item.dc:title: Want to make a difference? Try working at an environmental non-profit organization
item.dc:creator: Natasha Gilbert

item.title: Future of Humanity Institute shuts: what’s next for ‘deep future’ research?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01229-8

Researchers from several disciplines hope to predict — and prevent — scenarios that pose risks to humanity.
item.dc:title: Future of Humanity Institute shuts: what’s next for ‘deep future’ research?
item.dc:creator: David Adam

item.title: Garden-variety fungus is an expert at environmental clean-ups
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01145-x

The common fungus Aspergillus niger removes both heavy metals and organic pollutants from its surroundings.
item.dc:title: Garden-variety fungus is an expert at environmental clean-ups

item.title: Air-travel climate-change emissions detailed for nearly 200 nations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01148-8

Carbon emissions from flights that departed from low- and middle-income countries in 2019 totalled 417 million tonnes.
item.dc:title: Air-travel climate-change emissions detailed for nearly 200 nations

item.title: Rat neurons repair mouse brains — and restore sense of smell
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01222-1

Scientists develop hybrid mice by filling in missing cells and structures in their brains with rat stem cells.
item.dc:title: Rat neurons repair mouse brains — and restore sense of smell
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: Hello puffins, goodbye belugas: changing Arctic fjord hints at our climate future
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01128-y

Stunning images show an ecosystem’s upheaval as it warms at an alarming pace.
item.dc:title: Hello puffins, goodbye belugas: changing Arctic fjord hints at our climate future
item.dc:creator: Freda Kreier

item.title: Scientists urged to collect royalties from the ‘magic money tree’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01246-7

By joining a collecting society, researchers can ensure they are paid when copyrighted book content and papers are reproduced.
item.dc:title: Scientists urged to collect royalties from the ‘magic money tree’
item.dc:creator: Oscar Allan

item.title: Daily briefing: How an unlikely friendship with Jung influenced Pauli’s physics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01253-8

A patient–analyst relationship to psychoanalyst Carl Jung that evolved into a friendship deeply influenced physicist Wolfgang Pauli’s work. Plus, organoids shed light on cancer and other diseases, and medieval graves reveal secrets of a mysterious nomadic people.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: How an unlikely friendship with Jung influenced Pauli’s physics
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: China's Moon atlas is the most detailed ever made
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01223-0

The Geologic Atlas of the Lunar Globe doubles the resolution of Apollo-era maps and will support the space ambitions of China and other countries.
item.dc:title: China's Moon atlas is the most detailed ever made
item.dc:creator: Ling Xin

item.title: ‘Shut up and calculate’: how Einstein lost the battle to explain quantum reality
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01216-z

By suppressing questions they considered too ‘philosophical’, post-war physicists created an unquestioning orthodoxy that influences science to this day.
item.dc:title: ‘Shut up and calculate’: how Einstein lost the battle to explain quantum reality
item.dc:creator: Jim Baggott

item.title: Algorithm ranks peer reviewers by reputation — but critics warn of bias
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01235-w

There are questions about whether the tool, which could be used by editors to find and shortlist peer reviewers, would disadvantage inexperienced candidates or those in certain locations.
item.dc:title: Algorithm ranks peer reviewers by reputation — but critics warn of bias
item.dc:creator: Dalmeet Singh Chawla

item.title: NIH pay rise for postdocs and PhD students could have US ripple effect
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01242-x

Salary increases for the 17,000-plus recipients of an NIH research award could lead to increases in other academic settings.
item.dc:title: NIH pay rise for postdocs and PhD students could have US ripple effect
item.dc:creator: Amanda Heidt

item.title: Bird flu in US cows: is the milk supply safe?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01221-2

Pasteurized milk is probably not a threat to people, but fresh milk droplets on milking equipment could be spreading the virus in a herd.
item.dc:title: Bird flu in US cows: is the milk supply safe?
item.dc:creator: Julian Nowogrodzki

item.title: Judge dismisses superconductivity physicist’s lawsuit against university
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01231-0

Ranga Dias sued his university, in part, for allegedly conducting a biased investigation, which found he had committed extensive scientific misconduct.
item.dc:title: Judge dismisses superconductivity physicist’s lawsuit against university
item.dc:creator: Dan Garisto

item.title: NATO is boosting AI and climate research as scientific diplomacy remains on ice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01052-1

As the military alliance created to counter the Soviet Union expands, it is prioritizing studies on how climate change affects security, cyberattacks and election interference.
item.dc:title: NATO is boosting AI and climate research as scientific diplomacy remains on ice
item.dc:creator: Natasha Gilbert

item.title: Are robots the solution to the crisis in older-person care?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01184-4

Social robots that promise companionship and stimulation for older people and those with dementia are attracting investment, but some question their benefits.
item.dc:title: Are robots the solution to the crisis in older-person care?
item.dc:creator: Tammy Worth

item.title: Structures of human γδ T cell receptor–CD3 complex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07439-4

Structures of human γδ T cell receptor–CD3 complex
item.dc:title: Structures of human γδ T cell receptor–CD3 complex
item.dc:creator: Weizhi Xin
Bangdong Huang
Ximin Chi
Yuehua Liu

Yuanyuan Zhang

Qiang Zhou

item.title: How gliding marsupials got their ‘wings’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01230-1

Researchers find the genetic mutations that allow some marsupials to soar, and an ultra-accurate clock is put through its paces on the high seas.
item.dc:title: How gliding marsupials got their ‘wings’
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: First glowing animals lit up the oceans half a billion years ago
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01183-5

Family tree of ‘octocorals’ pushes origin of bioluminescence back to 540 million years ago, when the first animal species developed eyes.
item.dc:title: First glowing animals lit up the oceans half a billion years ago
item.dc:creator: Freda Kreier

item.title: Should the Maldives be creating new land?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01228-9

The Maldives are racing to reclaim vast amounts of land to combat rising sea levels. But many are concerned that these efforts risk harming the paradise they aims to protect
item.dc:title: Should the Maldives be creating new land?
item.dc:creator: Shamini Bundell
Jesse Chase-Lubitz

item.title: This giant extinct salmon had tusks like a warthog
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01146-w

Scientists initially thought that the outsized teeth were fangs, giving rise to the ‘sabre-toothed salmon’ nickname.
item.dc:title: This giant extinct salmon had tusks like a warthog

item.title: High-performance fibre battery with polymer gel electrolyte
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07343-x

A fibre lithium-ion battery that can potentially be woven into textiles shows enhanced battery performance and safety compared with liquid electrolytes.
item.dc:title: High-performance fibre battery with polymer gel electrolyte

item.title: Discovery of WRN inhibitor HRO761 with synthetic lethality in MSI cancers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07350-y

HRO761 is a potent, selective, allosteric WRN inhibitor that binds at the interface of the D1 and D2 helicase domains, locking WRN in an inactive conformation.
item.dc:title: Discovery of WRN inhibitor HRO761 with synthetic lethality in MSI cancers

item.title: Antisense oligonucleotide therapeutic approach for Timothy syndrome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07310-6

Antisense oligonucleotides effectively decrease the inclusion of exon  8A of CACNA1C in human cells both in vitro and in rodents transplanted with human brain organoids, and a single intrathecal administration rescued both calcium changes and in vivo dendrite morphology of patient neurons.
item.dc:title: Antisense oligonucleotide therapeutic approach for Timothy syndrome

item.title: Multi-project wafers for flexible thin-film electronics by independent foundries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07306-2

The iconic 6502 microprocessor designed in two key thin-film transistor technologies by independent foundries is used to demonstrate and expand the multi-project wafer approach for flexible electronics.
item.dc:title: Multi-project wafers for flexible thin-film electronics by independent foundries
item.dc:creator: Hikmet Çeliker
Wim Dehaene
Kris Myny

item.title: Growth of diamond in liquid metal at 1 atm pressure
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07339-7

Diamond crystals and polycrystalline diamond films can be grown using liquid metal at standard pressure and high temperature instead of conventional high pressure and high temperature.
item.dc:title: Growth of diamond in liquid metal at 1 atm pressure
item.dc:creator: Yan Gong

item.title: PGE<sub>2</sub> limits effector expansion of tumour-infiltrating stem-like CD8<sup>+</sup> T cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07254-x

Tumour-derived prostaglandin E2, signaling through its receptors EP2 and EP4, is shown to restrain the responses of tumour-infiltrating stem-like TCF1+CD8+ T lymphocytes, and modulation of T cell EP2 and EP4 can restore anticancer immunity.
item.dc:title: PGE<sub>2</sub> limits effector expansion of tumour-infiltrating stem-like CD8<sup>+</sup> T cells
item.dc:creator: Sebastian B. Lacher

item.title: A high-density and high-confinement tokamak plasma regime for fusion energy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07313-3

A stable tokamak plasma has been demonstrated with a high plasma density and a high energy confinement quality, both of which are simultaneously important for fusion reactors.
item.dc:title: A high-density and high-confinement tokamak plasma regime for fusion energy
item.dc:creator: S. Ding
A. M. Garofalo
H. Q. Wang
D. B. Weisberg

J. M. Hanson

item.title: Single-cell analysis reveals context-dependent, cell-level selection of mtDNA
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07332-0

A new method for tracking single-cell heteroplasmy, called SCI-LITE, is combined with mitochondrial DNA base editing to reveal principles of heteroplasmy dynamics in dividing cells.
item.dc:title: Single-cell analysis reveals context-dependent, cell-level selection of mtDNA
item.dc:creator: Anna V. Kotrys
Timothy J. Durham
Xiaoyan A. Guo
Venkata R. Vantaku
Sareh Parangi
Vamsi K. Mootha

item.title: Chemoproteomic discovery of a covalent allosteric inhibitor of WRN helicase
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07318-y

VVD-133214, a clinical-stage, covalent allosteric inhibitor of the helicase WRN, was well tolerated in mice and led to robust tumour regression in multiple microsatellite-instability-high colorectal cancer cell lines and patient-derived xenograft models.
item.dc:title: Chemoproteomic discovery of a covalent allosteric inhibitor of WRN helicase
item.dc:creator: Kristen A. Baltgalvis
Kelsey N. Lamb
Kent T. Symons

item.title: A magnetar giant flare in the nearby starburst galaxy M82
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07285-4

We report observations of GRB 231115A, positionally coincident with the starburst galaxy M82, that unambiguously qualify this burst as a giant flare from a magnetar, which is a rare explosive event releasing gamma rays.
item.dc:title: A magnetar giant flare in the nearby starburst galaxy M82

item.title: Whole-cortex in situ sequencing reveals input-dependent area identity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07221-6

BARseq interrogates the expression of 104 cell-type marker genes in 10.3 million cells over nine mouse forebrain hemispheres to reveal the role of peripheral inputs on cortical area development.
item.dc:title: Whole-cortex in situ sequencing reveals input-dependent area identity
item.dc:creator: Xiaoyin Chen
Stephan Fischer
Mara C. P. Rue
Aixin Zhang
Didhiti Mukherjee
Patrick O. Kanold
Jesse Gillis
Anthony M. Zador

item.title: Periportal macrophages protect against commensal-driven liver inflammation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07372-6

A subset of Macro-positive macrophages is identified to have immunosuppressive functions in the periportal vein zones of the liver to mediate excessive inflammation, and their effects depend on commensal gut bacteria.
item.dc:title: Periportal macrophages protect against commensal-driven liver inflammation
item.dc:creator: Yu Miyamoto
Junichi Kikuta

item.title: High carrier mobility along the [111] orientation in Cu<sub>2</sub>O photoelectrodes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07273-8

A study introduces a novel method to grow single-crystal Cu2O thin films with selected crystal orientations, highlighting enhanced bulk carrier mobility and carrier diffusion length along the [111] direction that yields Cu2O photocathodes with improved performance.
item.dc:title: High carrier mobility along the [111] orientation in Cu<sub>2</sub>O photoelectrodes
item.dc:creator: Linfeng Pan
Linjie Dai

item.title: Probing entanglement in a 2D hard-core Bose–Hubbard lattice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07325-z

By emulating a 2D hard-core Bose–Hubbard lattice using a controllable 4 × 4 array of superconducting qubits, volume-law entanglement scaling as well as area-law scaling at different locations in the energy spectrum are observed.
item.dc:title: Probing entanglement in a 2D hard-core Bose–Hubbard lattice
item.dc:creator: Amir H. Karamlou
Ilan T. Rosen

item.title: One-dimensional proximity superconductivity in the quantum Hall regime
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07271-w

We show that domain walls in minimally twisted bilayer graphene support exceptionally robust proximity superconductivity in the quantum Hall regime.
item.dc:title: One-dimensional proximity superconductivity in the quantum Hall regime
item.dc:creator: Julien Barrier
Minsoo Kim

item.title: Transient loss of Polycomb components induces an epigenetic cancer fate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07328-w

A transient perturbation of transcriptional silencing mediated by Polycomb proteins is sufficient to induce an epigenetic cancer cell fate in Drosophila in the absence of driver mutations.
item.dc:title: Transient loss of Polycomb components induces an epigenetic cancer fate
item.dc:creator: V. Parreno
V. Loubiere

item.title: Spatiotemporally resolved colorectal oncogenesis in mini-colons ex vivo
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07330-2

Topobiologically complex mini-colons—which enable the faithful in vitro recapitulation of colorectal cancer tumorigenesis and its environmental determinants—offer the possibility to reduce animal use in a wide range of experimental applications.
item.dc:title: Spatiotemporally resolved colorectal oncogenesis in mini-colons ex vivo
item.dc:creator: L. Francisco Lorenzo-Martín
Tania Hübscher
Amber D. Bowler
Nicolas Broguiere

Lucie Tillard
Mikhail Nikolaev
Freddy Radtke
Matthias P. Lutolf

item.title: Valleytronics in bulk MoS<sub>2</sub> with a topologic optical field
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07156-y

We develop an optical method that can set and read the state of electrons in the valley polarization of bulk transition metal dichalcogenide semiconductors, with potential utility as digital storage at quantum coherent timescales and application in quantum computing.
item.dc:title: Valleytronics in bulk MoS<sub>2</sub> with a topologic optical field
item.dc:creator: Igor Tyulnev
Álvaro Jiménez-Galán
Julita Poborska

Rui E. F. Silva
Jens Biegert

item.title: Regioselective hydroformylation of propene catalysed by rhodium-zeolite
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07342-y

Rhodium catalysts confined in zeolite pores exhibit high regioselectivity in the hydroformylation process of propene to high-value n-butanal, surpassing the performance of all heterogeneous and most homogeneous catalysts developed so far.
item.dc:title: Regioselective hydroformylation of propene catalysed by rhodium-zeolite
item.dc:creator: Xiangjie Zhang

item.title: Mechanism of single-stranded DNA annealing by RAD52–RPA complex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07347-7

Single-stranded DNA annealing is driven by RAD52 open rings in association with RPA.
item.dc:title: Mechanism of single-stranded DNA annealing by RAD52–RPA complex
item.dc:creator: Chih-Chao Liang
Luke A. Greenhough
Laura Masino
Sarah Maslen
Ilirjana Bajrami

Ian A. Taylor
Stephen C. West

item.title: Dearomatization drives complexity generation in freshwater organic matter
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07210-9

Using complementary multiplicity-edited 13C nuclear magnetic resonance spectra, oxidative dearomatization is shown to be a key driver for generating structural diversity during processing of dissolved organic matter and the data also suggest high abundance of OCqC3 units.
item.dc:title: Dearomatization drives complexity generation in freshwater organic matter
item.dc:creator: Siyu Li
Mourad Harir
